author: pdobacz
content: Thanks for the write up. I want to understand the interplay between EOF, 7702 and these use cases you mention. Is it that 7702's designation ~~revocability~~ mutability (enabling the front-running attack you mention) causes an EXTCODECOPY(target_address) be required before calling? There is no other pattern to protect against the front-running? (I tried to come up with one, but no idea so far). This seems like an argument against 7702 ~~revocability~~ mutability (admittedly, a can of worms) or an argument to revisit EOF's EXTCODECOPY (setting aside EXTCODETYPE for now).

author: pdobacz
content:
<@177224966398279680> <@1248276026736246889> 

Comment from <@425274498732916736> regarding your hackmd:
> I think the description of the CODECOPY is incorrect there.
> It should not read the delegation but the code being executed
7702 doesn't alter CODECOPY's behavior, as it does EXTCODECOPY's. Also an EEST test `test_self_code_on_set_code` confirms this is the case.

If we're not mistaken, the overall main point of the doc on designation introspection stands, just the CODECOPY-EXTCODECOPY consistency argument doesn't.
